content: This discussion on adjoint operators made me think of a little result that I proved a while ago, of which I'm fond, but I don't know what use to make of it. I'm sharing it here in hope that someone may have ideas about it.

When people talk of Hilb\mathrm{Hilb}Hilb, the category of Hilbert spaces, usually there's two possible choices of morphisms:

  • bounded linear maps, or
  • short linear maps, aka bounded maps with norm ≤1\leq 1≤1, aka norm-non-increasing maps.
    The second one has some nice properties, such as the fact that the only isomorphisms are the unitary isomorphisms; let's focus on that one.

From the point of view of universal algebra, these morphisms are still a bit odd, because they do not preserve the structure on vector spaces that makes them (pre-)Hilbert spaces, namely, the inner product. The morphisms that are “natural” from this point of view are only the isometries. Let's call Hilb1\mathrm{Hilb}_1Hilb1​ the category of Hilbert spaces and isometries.

Now Hilb1\mathrm{Hilb}_1Hilb1​ has pushouts, so we can enough to form the bicategory of cospans Cosp(Hilb1)\textit{Cosp}(\mathrm{Hilb}_1)Cosp(Hilb1​). This has as morphisms H→H′H \to H'H→H′ cospans H↪K↩H′H \hookrightarrow K \hookleftarrow H'H↪K↩H′ of isometries, and as 2-morphisms from H↪K↩H′H \hookrightarrow K \hookleftarrow H'H↪K↩H′ to H↪K′↩H′H \hookrightarrow K' \hookleftarrow H'H↪K′↩H′ isometries K↪K′K \hookrightarrow K'K↪K′ that make the two triangles commute.

Then, we can obtain canonically a category by “1-truncating”, that is, identifying any two morphisms which are connected by a 2-morphism. This is similar to how, for example, the category of sets and relations is the 1-truncation of the bicategory of spans of sets.
The result is:

Proposition: The 1-truncation of Cosp(Hilb1)\textit{Cosp}(\mathrm{Hilb}_1)Cosp(Hilb1​) is equivalent to Hilb\mathrm{Hilb}Hilb.

Moreover, bicategories of spans and cospans have a canonical “dagger”, that is a direction-reversing involution on morphisms between two objects, which simply exchanges the two sides of the (co)span.
Denoting by τ\tauτ the truncation, if fff is a cospan of isometries and f†f^\dagf† its dual cospan, we have that τ(f†)=τ(f)†\tau(f^\dag) = \tau(f)^\dagτ(f†)=τ(f)†, the adjoint of τ(f)\tau(f)τ(f). Thus we recover adjoint maps from the natural dagger of cospans.

The reason I like this result is that it reconstructs Hilb\mathrm{Hilb}Hilb and its dagger structure, which are both somewhat odd from the point of view of categorical algebra, from

  • Hilb1\mathrm{Hilb}_1Hilb1​, which is a full subcategory of a category of models of an algebraic theory,
  • the “cospan bicategory” and “truncation” operations, which are natural categorical constructions.
But I don't know in what direction this could be taken! Is there anything interesting about the 2-morphisms of Cosp(Hilb1)\textit{Cosp}(\mathrm{Hilb}_1)Cosp(Hilb1​)?

One thing that seemed “suggestive” to me is the following: TQFTs are formalised as monoidal functors from a category of cobordisms to the category of Hilbert spaces. But a cobordism is a cospan of embeddings of manifolds, modulo some equivalence.

  • Question: * Are there “nice” TQFTs that lift to a functor of bicategories of cospans, or maybe come from just an assignments of isometries to embeddings, via the cospan construction?

My knowledge of TQFTs is not nearly enough to approach this!
is the Hilb\mathrm{Hilb}Hilb in your proposition the category with bounded maps or short ones? such a nice result though! is this studied anywhere?

This is nice!
Is there a classical analogue? I'd say the analogue of isometries would be injective functions. So I think the cospans would be partial injections. That makes sense as a classical analogue of norm-decreasing maps.

@Tim Hosgood It's the short ones. The cospan H↪K↩H′H\hookrightarrow K \hookleftarrow H'H↪K↩H′ corresponds to the map that sends HHH to H′H'H′ by projecting the image of HHH in KKK onto the image of H′H'H′. This is always short.

Oscar Cunningham said:

This is nice!
Is there a classical analogue? I'd say the analogue of isometries would be injective functions. So I think the cospans would be partial injections. That makes sense as a classical analogue of norm-decreasing maps.

Yes, exactly: one gets the category of partial injections. In fact the ℓ2\ell^2ℓ2 functor defined by your supervisor Chris Heunen arises from this construction applied to its restriction from (sets, injections) to (Hilbert spaces, isometries).
Of course, partial injections are more easily obtained as spans of injections. But spans of isometries only give you partial isometries.

So, since operators on a single Hilbert space are so important in the theory, something we can do is look at the hom-category [H,H][H,H][H,H] in the bicategory of cospans, above the hom-set of short operators on HHH -- which is of course a monoidal category...

In the simplest case of 000 the trivial Hilbert space, there is a unique map 0→00 \to 00→0 in Hilb\mathrm{Hilb}Hilb. But there is a (unique) cospan of isometries 0→00 \to 00→0 for each Hilbert space HHH...
Morphisms between these cospans are exactly injections of Hilbert spaces, and their composition is a pushout of morphisms from the initial object, ie a coproduct, ie a direct sum of Hilbert spaces.
So the monoidal category [0,0][0,0][0,0] is equivalent to (Hilb1,⊕,0)(\mathrm{Hilb}_1, \oplus, 0)(Hilb1​,⊕,0).

(I guess that will be true of the cospan bicategory on any category with pushouts and an initial object -- the hom-category on the initial object is the original category with the monoidal structure given by coproducts).

What is a monoid in [0,0][0,0][0,0], ie a monad on 000 in Cosp(Hilb1)\textit{Cosp}(\mathrm{Hilb}_1)Cosp(Hilb1​)? Let HHH be a Hilbert space, corresponding to a morphism 0→00 \to 00→0. There is always a unique 2-morphism id0⇒H\mathrm{id}_0 \Rightarrow Hid0​⇒H, so that will have to be the unit.
The multiplication is an isometry H⊕H↪HH \oplus H \hookrightarrow HH⊕H↪H. So there can be one only if HHH is infinite-dimensional.
(Or 000)
But unitality would force both the components to be the identity, but that's not an isometry unless H=0H = 0H=0... so I don't think there's any interesting monoid.
I vaguely recall isometries H⊕H↪HH \oplus H \hookrightarrow HH⊕H↪H being relevant to Geometry of Interaction, though.

(Now that I think about it, I haven't told the story exactly right. It's not true that direct sum is a coproduct in Hilb1\mathrm{Hilb}_1Hilb1​ -- in fact it only satisfies a universal property wrt pullback squares... but that's enough to still define a composition of cospans, and a bicategory of them...)
(Which is why instead of getting “a unique monoid on every object” as we should in a cocartesian category, we don't really get any nontrivial ones :grimacing:)

Usually "nice" TQFTs lift in various ways. The most productive way to go up one notch is to consider symmetric monoidal 2-functors from
[(n-2)-manifolds, cobordisms, cobordisms between cobordisms]
to
[2-Hilbert spaces, linear functors, natural transformations]

I think this is a description of a bicategory equivalent to Cosp(Hilb1)\textit{Cosp}(\mathrm{Hilb}_1)Cosp(Hilb1​), which may be easier to work with to understand what is going on.

Objects are still Hilbert spaces.
Now a morphism H→H′H \to H'H→H′ is given by a pair of Hilbert spaces K0,K1K_0, K_1K0​,K1​, together with a unitary isomorphism u:H⊕K0→H′⊕K1u: H \oplus K_0 \to H' \oplus K_1u:H⊕K0​→H′⊕K1​.
I will denote such a morphism just by u:H⊕K0→H′⊕K1u: H \oplus K_0 \to H' \oplus K_1u:H⊕K0​→H′⊕K1​, since it contains all the information...

A 2-morphism from u:H⊕K0→H′⊕K1u: H \oplus K_0 \to H' \oplus K_1u:H⊕K0​→H′⊕K1​ to u′:H⊕K0′→H′⊕K1′u': H \oplus K'_0 \to H' \oplus K'_1u′:H⊕K0′​→H′⊕K1′​ is a pair of isometries i0:K0↪K0′,i1:K1↪K1′i_0: K_0 \hookrightarrow K'_0, i_1: K_1 \hookrightarrow K'_1i0​:K0​↪K0′​,i1​:K1​↪K1′​ with the property that

(idH⊕i0);u′=u;(idH′⊕i1)(\mathrm{id}_H \oplus i_0) ; u' = u ; (\mathrm{id}_{H'} \oplus i_1)(idH​⊕i0​);u′=u;(idH′​⊕i1​).
Vertical composition of 2-morphisms is just composing the isometries pairwise.

The horizontal composition of u:H⊕K0→H′⊕K1u: H \oplus K_0 \to H' \oplus K_1u:H⊕K0​→H′⊕K1​ and of v:H′⊕K0′→H′′⊕K1′v: H' \oplus K'_0 \to H'' \oplus K'_1v:H′⊕K0′​→H′′⊕K1′​ is

... well, the unitary isomorphism H⊕(K0⊕K0′)→H′′⊕(K1⊕K1′)H \oplus (K_0 \oplus K'_0) \to H'' \oplus (K_1 \oplus K'_1)H⊕(K0​⊕K0′​)→H′′⊕(K1​⊕K1′​) that you get by composing uuu and vvv along H′H'H′ and permuting inputs and outputs when necessary (writing it down explicitly is not very illuminating).
And the horizontal composite of two 2-morphisms should be clear: just stick the isometries “one next to another” in the direct sums...
